elements.content: A three-dimensional chiral metal formate framework compound, [NH4][Zn(HCOO)3], undergoes a paraelectric−ferroelectric phase transition at 191 K triggered by the disorder−order transition of NH4 + cations within the structure.

elements.content: Ferroelectric materials are of importance and interest in both basic scientific concerns and versatile technological applications. The majorities are perovskite oxides such as BaTiO3 and lead zirconate titanate (PZT); hydrogen-bonded inorganic salts such as Rochelle salt, potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP), and triglycine sulfate (TGS); and recently reported organic ones. In the later classes, H bonding plays the key role in the electric ordering. The recently developed metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have shown various properties or functionalities due to their hybrid inorganic−organic nature, but ferroelectric MOFs still remain scarce. Except for the symmetry requirement for ferroelectrics, H-bonding systems can easily be created within MOFs if suitable components with H-bond donors and acceptors are chosen and properly organized in the solid state. Therefore, MOFs are promising candidates for ferroelectrics. On the other hand, the combination of the magnetism of MOFs with ferroelectricity should result in multiferroelectrics. In this context, we have systematically explored magnetic metal formate frameworks templated by protonated organic amines. Cheetham and other workers have shown that in our first-reported magnetic perovskite [(CH3)2NH2][MII(HCOO)3] series the antiferroelectricity occurs in the 160−185 K range and that the disorder−order transition of the (CH3)2NH2 + template is the origin of electric ordering. We observed that the porous magnetic host framework of [Mn3(HCOO)6] with polar guests can lead to interesting dielectric properties, including ferroelectricity. These are new multiferroics. Very recently, we have found that the [NH4][MII(HCOO)3] series shows a structural phase transition in which the disordered NH4 + cation at room temperature (RT) becomes ordered at low temperature (LT). In this communication, we report that [NH4][Zn(HCOO)3] (1) shows a paraelectric−ferroelectric transition at the critical temperature T C = 191 K, as characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), dielectric anomaly, dielectric hysteresis loop, and preliminary thermodynamic studies, and we show that this is related to the disorder−order transition of the NH4 + cations within the structure.

elements.content: 1 was prepared by reaction of ammonium formate, formic acid, and Zn(ClO4)·6H2O in methanol (see the ). The bulk phase purity was verified by powder XRD (Figure S1 in the ), and the material was thermally stable up to 100 °C (). The slow diffusion method afforded hexagonal plate or bipyramidal crystals () up to 2 mm in size.

elements.content: The structures of 1 at both 290 and 110 K were determined (Figure ; also see ). Here we focus on H-bonding systems and structural changes related to the ferroelectricity of 1. At 290 K, the crystal belongs to the hexagonal space group P6322, which has the nonpolar point group D 6, with a 290K = 7.3084(2) Å, c 290K = 8.1705(3) Å, and V 290K = 377.94(2) Å3. The crystal structure is the same as that of [NH4][M(HCOO)3] (M = Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+); it features a three-dimensional chiral anionic [Zn(HCOO)3 −] framework having a (49·66) network topology (Figure a), with the arrays of NH4 + cations located in the framework’s helical channels along the c direction (). Each octahedral Zn2+ node connects to six neighbors through anti−anti formate bridges. In the channel, the unique NH4 + cation shows disorder in a trigonal antiprism and forms 6 × 2/3 = 4 N−H···O hydrogen bonds to the anionic framework, with a N···O distance of 2.972 Å and a N−H···O angle of 161° (Figure b). The disorder of the NH4 + indicates the competition among different H-bonding sites at room temperature. Disorder of protonated ammine cations has been observed for many metal formate compounds.

elements.content: 1 was observed to undergo a structural phase transition at ∼190 K, accompanied by the tripling of the unit cell, the disorder−order transition of NH4 + with related structure changes (Figure and ), and a change in space group from P6322 to the polar P63. The length of c 110K axis, 8.2015(2) Å, is slightly longer than c 290K, while a 110K becomes the diagonal (a−b)290K of the (ab)290K rhombus, whose length of 12.5919(3) Å is very close to 31/2 a 290K; therefore, V 110K = 1126.18(5) Å3, which is almost equal to 3V 290K. The tripling of the unit cell at 110 K was also evidenced by the observation of weak diffraction spots in the oscillation image at 110 K that were not observed at 290 K (). Thus, the unique channel at (0, 0, z) in the 290 K structure was split into three unique channels at (0, 0, z), (2/3, 1/3, z), and (1/3, 2/3, z), locating three unique, ordered, tetrahedral NH4 + cations, each with one apical and three basal N−H groups. Each basal N−H group forms a stronger H bond to the metal formate framework, with N···O distances of 2.830−2.864 Å and N−H···O angles of 167−175°. The apical N−H group, with the N−H directing c axis, still forms a trifurcated acceptor-type H bond, with N···O distances of 3.075−3.120 Å and N−H···O angles of 103−105°. It is noted that within the unit cell, the NH4 + cations in the channels at (2/3, 1/3, z) and (1/3, 2/3, z) have their apical N−H groups pointing in the +c direction, but the NH4 + cations in the channel at (0, 0, z) have the apical N−H groups pointing in the opposite direction. More importantly, the N atoms of the NH4 + cations in the three channels are shifted by −0.36, −0.38, and +0.40 Å along the c direction with respect to the anionic framework compared to the zero shift in the 290 K structure, which has a zero shift (); this indicates the double potential wells for the NH4 + cations in the channel. These are related to the polar LT structure and the observed ferroelectricity. The C 6 point group of the LT phase is a subgroup of the D 6 point group of the RT phase in which the twofold axes have vanished, indicating the symmetry breaking and coinciding with a typical ferroelectric type of 622F6 in the Aizu notation.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the dielectric permittivity (ε) of 1 was measured on a single crystal of 1 () under an applied electric field E ∥ c with frequencies of 100 Hz to 1 MHz. Indeed, the real component, ε′, showed very high dielectric anomaly peaks at 191−192 K (Figure a), corresponding to the transition. The peak ε′ values are several or tens-fold larger than those at higher and lower temperatures. This is characteristic of a ferroelectric transition. The reciprocal ε′ data at 10 kHz between 210 and 260 K fitted the Curie−Weiss law well (), affording the Curie constant C = 5.39 × 103 K and the Curie−Weiss temperature T 0 = 181 K. The C value is comparable to those of ferroelectrics undergoing disorder−order transitions of H-bonding systems, such as KDP and TGS, and T 0 is slightly lower than T C = 191 K.

elements.content: The ferroelectricity was confirmed by the dielectric hysteresis loops of polarization measured with E ∥ c below T C (Figure b). The characteristic loop clearly occurred at 189 K, just below T C. The spontaneous polarization increased on cooling and reached saturation at 163 K with a remnant polarization (P r) of 0.68 μC cm−2, a coercive field (E c) of 2.8 kV cm−1, and a saturation spontaneous polarization (P s) of 1.03 μC cm−2, all of which are typical for H-bonded ferroelectrics. In the LT phase, the shifts of NH4 + cations related to the anionic framework could be considered to create dipoles with ± unit charges separated by these shifts along the c axis, from which P s could be easily estimated as 0.96 μC cm−2, in agreement with the above experimental value.

elements.content: 1 was subjected preliminary differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and specific heat (C P ) measurements (both in heating mode; Figure c). An endothermic peak in the DSC curve and a λ-shaped peak in the C P data were clearly observed at 192 K, corresponding to the paraelectric−ferroelectric transition. The ΔH and ΔS were estimated as ∼0.7 kJ mol−1 and ∼2 J mol−1 K−1, respectively. From the Boltzmann equation, ΔS = R ln N, where R is the gas constant and N is the ratio of the numbers of respective geometrically distinguishable orientations, we obtain N = 1.3. This value is less than the value N = 2 denoting two discrete states in the disorder phase, indicating the discomplicated disordered−ordered feature of the phase transition. These results confirm the phase transition, though the thermodynamic characteristics need further investigation.

elements.content: In conclusion, the paraelectric−ferroelectric phase transition at 191 K triggered by the disorder−order transition of NH4 + cations in the metal formate framework of 1 has successfully been established. As a large number of magnetic metal formate frameworks templated by various protonated amines have been discovered, the finding of ferroelectricity in 1 opens an avenue to a new class of MOF-based multiferroics, and this research is underway.
